title: Investors Looking to Escape Volatility Turn to 'Smart' ETFs
summary: Two of the biggest exchange-traded funds that try to pick less volatile stocks have been among the most popular so far this year. Investors hunting for protection after last year's market turbulence are snapping up so-called smart funds in the hopes of sidestepping the next downturn.

title: High Court Ruling Threatens Asset-Seizure Programs
summary: Ruling potentially jeopardizes asset-forfeiture programs that help pay for police operations. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court ruled unanimously Wednesday that states may not impose excessive fines, extending a bedrock constitutional protection but potentially jeopardizing asset-forfeiture programs that help fund police operations with property seized from criminal suspects.

title: Lyft Plans to List Shares on Nasdaq
summary: Ride-hailing company expected to make IPO filing public as early as next week. Lyft Inc. is preparing to list its shares on Nasdaq around the end of March, as the ride-sharing firm's hotly anticipated plan to join the public markets comes into focus.

title: How to Liberate Amazon Workers
summary: A $150,000 salary goes a lot further in Virginia or Tennessee than it would in high-tax New York City.. Progressives are touting Amazon's decision to cancel its plan to build a headquarters in New York as a great victory over "corporate greed," "worker exploitation" and "the richest man in the world." This may well turn out to be a victory for workers, exploited or otherwise, but perhaps not in the way progressives intend. As Amazon disperses its 25,000 employees earning an average of $150,000 annually to other locations, let's take a look at what it could mean for those employees who end up living in regions more capitalist than socialist.

title: A Taliban Precedent? Mao That You Mention It . . .
summary: Afghan peace talks look like the 1945 negotiations that led to communist victory in China.. Peace talks between the Taliban and the U.S. have brought back memories of the negotiations that led to the end of America's war in Vietnam. They're also reminiscent of an earlier effort by the U.S. to bring about a peace deal in Asia-specifically, in China after World War II. That effort ended in complete failure.

title: Mexican Meth Fuels an American Crisis
summary: Greater border security and funding for treatment are necessary to arrest the surge in deaths.. The opioid crisis grabs the headlines, but what about the meth crisis? Methamphetamine, produced by Mexican cartels and smuggled over the southwestern border, killed 10,333 Americans in 2017, more than in any previous year. Worse, preliminary statistics show an increase to more than 12,000 in the year ending last July. President Trump says there's a "crisis" at the border, and he's right-its result is the meth-overdose epidemic.

title: The Green New Deal's Impossible Electric Grid
summary: Renewable energy can't consistently balance power supply with demand.. The Democrats' Green New Deal calls for a fully renewable electric power grid. Regardless of the economic or political challenges of bringing this about, it is likely technologically impossible.

title: The Democrats' Socialist Gene
summary: Kamala Harris says, "I am not a democratic socialist." She should take a DNA test.. How did the Democratic Party move so far left so fast? No convention, retreat or caucus was held to designate Medicare for All, tippy-top tax rates, arcane identity litmus tests, free college tuition or a Green New Deal as Democratic dogma, but here we are.

title: 'Every Billionaire Is a Policy Mistake'
summary: The new Democratic Party wants to tear down the wealthy, not raise up the poor.. It's not your parents' Democratic Party anymore.

title: Nestlé, McDonald's, Others Pull Ads From YouTube
summary: Several companies suspended advertising on YouTube following a report documenting material on the video service that sexually exploits children. Several companies including Nestlé SA and "Fortnite" maker Epic Games Inc. suspended advertising on YouTube Wednesday following a report documenting material on the video service that sexually exploits children.

title: A Baseball Slugfest to Remember
summary: The Cardinals jumped a pair of sportswriters, who were not cowed.. Major League Baseball's preseason games begin Thursday. But nothing that happens on or off any diamond is likely to match the most downright delirious day in spring-training history.

title: 'The Story of Silver' Review: The Other Precious Metal
summary: The value of silver-not to mention its legendary role in the world's monetary affairs-is capable of driving some people crazy.. We all want dollars, but who can define that object of desire? It was easy in 1792. Alexander Hamilton declared that the dollar was a unit of account weighing 371.25 grains of pure silver, and death was the penalty for debasing it. "The Story of Silver" is the biography of America's first monetary metal.

title: Pinterest Blocks Vaccination Searches
summary: Social-media company stops showing results on the topic as it looks to censor unsubstantiated health claims. Pinterest has stopped returning results for searches related to vaccinations, a drastic step the social-media company said is aimed at curbing the spread of misinformation but one that demonstrates the power of tech companies to censor discussion of hot-button issues.

title: More Virginians Support Northam Staying in Office, Polls Find
summary: Opinions mixed on whether Fairfax should resign; blacks less likely to call for both politicians to step down. Virginians are more likely to support Gov. Ralph Northam staying in office than leaving, according to two new polls, despite politicians' widespread demand for the governor to exit over a racist yearbook photo.

title: Lawsuit Challenges Connecticut's Racial Integration Efforts for Magnet Schools
summary: Plaintiffs allege the state's enrollment standards discriminate against black and Hispanic students. A conservative nonprofit representing a group of parents filed a federal lawsuit against Connecticut Wednesday, arguing the state's enrollment standards for its magnet schools are discriminatory.

title: VC Keith Rabois Bolts From Khosla Ventures to Join Peter Thiel's Founders Fund
summary: Investor, a former leader at payments startup Square, also co-founded home-sales platform Opendoor. Keith Rabois, a prolific and eclectic venture capitalist whose investments include home-selling platform Opendoor Labs Inc. and delivery startup DoorDash Inc., is leaving Khosla Ventures and joining Founders Fund, where he'll serve as general partner.

title: Investor Starboard Unhappy With Bristol-Myers' Deal to Buy Celgene
summary: Another shareholder, Dodge & Cox, is also unhappy. Activist investor Starboard Value LP is unhappy with Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. 's deal to buy rival Celgene Corp. , and it has moved to install its own set of directors at Bristol-Myers.

title: U.S. Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Trademark Disputes in Bankruptcy Cases
summary: An industry group has called the matter the most significant unresolved legal issue in trademark licensing. WASHINGTON-U.S. Supreme Court justices are weighing whether trademark users should have more protections in licensing disputes that break out in corporate bankruptcy cases.

title: Lowball Prices on Stock Options Could Be Silicon Valley's Juiciest Perk
summary: The stock valuations companies report ahead of an IPO can be significantly below what outside investors would pay-creating a future windfall for employees. Silicon Valley startups are often eager to tout their soaring values. But they are far more pessimistic when they hand out stock before going public-a sleight of hand that creates a hidden future windfall for employees while potentially lowering their taxes.

title: Dollar Rises After Federal Reserve's Minutes
summary: The dollar inched higher along with 10-year Treasury yields. The U.S. dollar bounced higher on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve's release of minutes from its Jan. 29-30 meeting.

title: Thousands Mourn Fallen NYPD Detective
summary: Brian Simonsen, a 19-year police department veteran, was killed last week while responding to a robbery in Queens. Thousands of mourners on Wednesday gathered at a Long Island church for the funeral of a New York Police Department detective who was killed last week while responding to a robbery in Queens.

title: Soured Pension Investments Spark Lawsuit Against Ex-Newspaper Owners
summary: Federal pension safety net sues Orange County Register former owners. Back in 2012, when California's Orange County Register was struggling in the aftermath of a pass through bankruptcy, former greeting card executive Aaron Kushner and Eric Spitz, now a leading light of California's cannabis industry, had a plan for reviving the newspaper.

title: Self-Storage Startup Clutter Gets $200 Million in Fresh Capital
summary: SoftBank Vision Fund and venture capitalists back firm despite recent flameouts like Shyp and Trove Technologies. Investors are showing renewed confidence in at least one startup focused on the on-demand moving-and-storage business despite some recent failures.

title: Fed Prepares to End Balance-Sheet Runoff Later This Year
summary: Minutes from the meeting show a split over whether officials believed any interest-rate increases would be necessary this year. Most Federal Reserve officials last month indicated they were ready to stop shrinking the central bank's $4 trillion asset portfolio this year and believed an action plan should be released soon.

title: Samsung Can't Bend Smartphone Market Realities
summary: More phones at higher prices don't counter a sluggish market-just ask Apple. Samsung Electronics clearly took a page from Apple Inc. with this year's crop of new smartphones. It will probably learn a painful lesson from its rival as well.

title: Cognizant Case Shows How Firms Can Avoid Charges Even Amid Alleged Wrongdoing
summary: Prosecutors declined to charge the company, citing recent enforcement policies. The case of Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp. shows how a company can avoid criminal charges even if its C-Suite was involved in alleged wrongdoing.

title: New York City Subway Rider Dies After Being Dragged by Train
summary: Accident renews talk of adding screen doors to platforms to prevent mishaps. Transit and police officials are investigating the death of a 39-year-old man who was dragged by a subway train into a tunnel at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Glencore, the King of Coal, Bows to Investor Pressure Over Climate
summary: Mining giant plans to limit coal production, despite having plowed billions of dollars into the fossil fuel. LONDON- Glencore PLC, one of the world's biggest coal producers, said it is capping output of the fossil fuel as it faces growing pressure from investors over climate change.

title: Oil Prices Reach Three-Month Highs on OPEC Cuts
summary: U.S. crude tops $57 a barrel, notching sixth straight session of gains. • Oil prices climbed to a three-month high on Wednesday on declining supply from OPEC and as investors awaited news on the U.S.-China trade negotiations.

title: Putin Ratchets Up Nuclear Warning Against U.S.
summary: Russia isn't seeking confrontation with the U.S. and wouldn't make the first move to deploy missiles. MOSCOW-President Vladimir Putin said Russia would target the U.S. with new advanced weapons if Washington deploys intermediate-range missiles in Europe, a threat that appeared aimed at holding the line but leaving open the possibility of negotiations after the breakdown of a nuclear treaty.

title: U.S. Stocks Hold Gains After Fed Minutes
summary: Cautious signals from the Fed and optimism about a U.S.-China trade agreement have sparked this year's rebound. U.S. stocks edged higher Wednesday, continuing a recent rally after minutes from the Federal Reserve's latest meeting showed officials agreed to signal a pause in interest-rate increases until they could better judge rising risks to economic growth

title: Metropolitan Opera's New Season to Include 'Porgy and Bess'
summary: Productions will also feature works by Handel and Philip Glass. The Metropolitan Opera's 2019-20 season will feature new productions of works by composers ranging from Handel to Gershwin to Philip Glass, company officials announced Wednesday.

title: Swedbank Shares Tumble Following Report Alleging Money Laundering
summary: Nordic bank handled $5.8 billion in suspicious funds, the report said. Shares of Nordic lender Swedbank AB tumbled more than 13% Wednesday in Swedish markets following a report alleging the bank handled billions in suspicious funds, some of which could be traced to a massive money-laundering scandal at Danske Bank A/S.

title: Trump Continues to Weigh EU Auto Tariffs
summary: President says possible levies depend on trade talks; 'We're trying to make a deal'. WASHINGTON-President Trump said Wednesday the U.S. would impose auto tariffs on the European Union if a trade deal can't be reached between the two sides, as tensions between the traditional allies continue to build.

title: The Fed's Temporary Cover
summary: Central-bank minutes show worries about growth but not about inflation; that could change if the economy picks up in the coming months. The Federal Reserve has put its plans for rate increases on hold, and for a while the economy should give it cover. But a while isn't forever.

title: Gannett's Loss Widens as Ad, Circulation Revenue Fall
summary: The publisher of USA Today has rejected a takeover proposal from Digital First, calling it inadequate. Gannett Co. , which is facing a takeover bid, reported a wider loss for its latest quarter as advertisers continued to turn away from print media and circulation revenue fell.

title: 'In Focus: A Complete Map of the World-The 18th-Century Convergence of China and Europe' Review: Shrinking an Expanding Globe
summary: While the striking map at the heart of this show placed China at the center of the world, cross-cultural exchanges can be seen in the chart itself and the other decorative objects in the exhibition..

title: Civilians Held by Islamic State in Syria Go Free
summary: The move suggested the extremists were near surrendering to U.S.-backed Kurdish forces, eliminating their last sliver of territory. Several hundred of the last civilians trapped by Islamic State in the militant group's remaining sliver of territory left on Wednesday, suggesting the extremist group was near a surrender to U.S.-backed Kurdish forces.

title: HSBC Co-Head of Global Banking to Leave
summary: Robin Phillips will leave the bank this summer. HSBC Holdings PLC co-head of global banking Robin Phillips will leave the bank this summer, a person familiar with the matter said Wednesday, following the hiring of a new co-head last October.

title: Health-Care Spending Set to Accelerate as Population Ages
summary: Expenditures are likely to grow because of new drugs, more seniors who will need hospital care, and an expanded Medicaid population. WASHINGTON-The growth in U.S. health-care spending is expected to accelerate over the coming eight years as baby boomers age and the prices for medical services grow, the Trump administration said Wednesday.

title: Treasury Yields Drift Higher After Fed Minutes
summary: Analysts struggle with uncertainty over direction Fed will take with rates. U.S. Treasury prices drifted lower Wednesday after minutes from the Federal Reserve's January meeting showed central bankers were divided on whether they would have to raise interest rates later this year.

title: Zimbabwe Abandons Its Dollar Peg, Effectively Introduces New Currency
summary: Central bank says electronic bank savings and locally printed 'bond notes' were no longer exchangeable one-to-one for the dollar. HARARE, Zimbabwe-Zimbabwe, which has been using the U.S. dollar for the past decade, effectively introduced its own currency again, admitting that dollars stored in local bank accounts are worth only a fraction of their stated value.

title: American Firm, Citing Ethics Code, Won't Sell Genetic Sequencers in Xinjiang
summary: Critics in U.S. say the products used for state surveillance of citizens enable human rights abuses. Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. said it will no longer be selling or servicing genetic sequencers in China's Xinjiang region, following mounting criticism that its products were used for state surveillance of citizens there that enabled human rights abuses.

title: Samsung Galaxy S10 First Look: More Phones, More Cameras, More Money
summary: Multiple rear cameras, an in-screen fingerprint sensor-and one 5G model-add excitement as smartphone sales slow. Phones with various screen sizes and colors? Yep!

title: Copper Hits Highest Level Since July
summary: Optimism on U.S.-China trade talks and a rally in oil lift prices. Copper prices rose to their highest level since July on Wednesday, boosted by optimism on trade talks between the U.S. and China and a rally in oil.

title: 'Signature' by Matthew Shipp Review: Where Radical Thinkers Are Prime Movers
summary: As the head of his trio, Mr. Shipp's ability to lure, more so than to lead, his associates into the wild thicket of ideas proposed by his playing makes for transformative musical exchanges..

title: Deutsche Bank Lost $1.6 Billion on a Bond Bet
summary: One of the banking industry's biggest soured bets since the financial crisis involved a complex municipal-bond investment. Warren Buffett was enmeshed in the deal.. Deutsche Bank AG racked up a loss of $1.6 billion over nearly a decade on a complex municipal-bond investment that it bought in the runup to the 2008 financial crisis, and failed to confront head-on even as markets were upended and regulations tightened.

title: Cyber Startup to Offer Refunds to Buyers of Its Crypto Token
summary: Gladius settles SEC probe over the sale of its GLA tokens to about 1,700 investors. WASHINGTON-A startup that helps clients fight off cybersecurity attacks agreed to offer refunds to investors who purchased millions of dollars worth of its digital tokens after regulators alleged the sale broke laws meant to inform them about business risks.

title: Connecticut's Lamont Calls for Pension Changes, Expanded Sales Tax
summary: Governor's first budget proposal calls for $43.2 billion in spending over next two years. HARTFORD, Conn.-Gov. Ned Lamont presented his first budget proposal Wednesday, suggesting sweeping changes to pensions and an expanded sales tax to close a $3.7 billion deficit projected over the next two years.

title: CVS Gives Downbeat Outlook for First Year as Merged Company
summary: Health-care company says results would be dragged down by challenges in its pharmacy-benefits and long-term-care businesses. CVS Health Corp. offered a downbeat earnings projection for 2019, its first year as a merged health-care company, saying results would be dragged down by challenges in areas including its pharmacy-benefits and long-term-care businesses.

title: New York Diverts Mighty Amazon's Proposal
summary: With a $3 billion reduction in taxes to New York over 25 years, Amazon and its employees would still have paid higher taxes in New York than they now will in nearly any other state.. Regarding your editorial "Amazon Escapes From New York" (Feb. 15): Do those who protested Amazon's plan prefer no jobs and no tax revenue instead of receiving a bit less-$27 billion in taxes over 25 years instead of $30 billion? Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez isn't alone in confusing tax reductions with government payments. New York levies nearly the highest taxes in the U.S. Even with a $3 billion reduction in taxes to New York over 25 years, Amazon and its employees would still have paid higher taxes in New York than they now will in nearly any other state. If states and cities want to attract employers, perhaps they should create tax policies that don't penalize capital-intensive companies, innovation, work and success.

title: Abraham Lincoln Really Was the Emancipator
summary: It became clear that slavery as an American institution couldn't stand in those border states not in rebellion if freedom prevailed in those states in rebellion.. Regarding Allen C. Guelzo's "Emancipation Deniers Target Lincoln's Reputation" (op-ed, Feb. 12): Historians attempting to minimize Abraham Lincoln's leadership in freeing the slaves in favor of advancing the theme that the slaves freed themselves should consider what Lincoln did to bring Great Britain to his way of thinking. Lincoln made public his Emancipation Proclamation on Sept. 22, 1862 but declared it would go into effect Jan. 1, 1863. His proclamation of freedom applied only to slave states still in rebellion. On Oct. 7, 1862 the Times of London presupposed what Lincoln was up to, and ran the following editorial: "This means, of course, that Mr. Lincoln will, on the 1st of next January do his best to excite a servile war in the States, which he cannot occupy with his arms. . . . He will run up the rivers in his gunboats; he will seek out the places which are left but slightly guarded, and where women and children have been trusted to the fidelity of coloured domestics. . . . he [Lincoln] will whisper the pleasures of spoil and of the gratification of yet fiercer instincts." At the time this was published, many politicians of Great Britain seriously considered recognizing the Confederacy. The Union blockade of Confederate cotton shut down much of Britain's textile industry.

title: Don't Just Cut and Run From Afghanistan
summary: The Trump administration's haste to leave Afghanistan will make the country less stable and render the U.S. more vulnerable to the threats we have paid dearly to prevent over the last 17 years.. As your editorial "Trump's 'Endless Wars' and Peace" (Feb. 8) suggests, the Trump administration's haste to leave Afghanistan will make the country less stable, prosperous and secure and render the U.S. more vulnerable to the threats we have paid dearly to prevent over the last 17 years.

title: Kellogg's New Pringles Fail to Make Waves
summary: The maker of Pringles potato chips isn't having an easy time bringing innovation to tired brands.. There has been plenty of innovation in the food industry in recent years, but not enough of it has come from the giant owners of tired brands. Kellogg , which touted its latest innovations at a consumer conference Wednesday, needs to try harder.

title: UBS Fined $4.2 Billion in French Tax-Evasion Case
summary: Judges find the Swiss lender guilty of illegally recruiting clients in France and helping them launder money that wasn't declared to authorities. French judges ordered UBS Group AG on Wednesday to pay a record €3.7 billion ($4.2 billion) fine for helping wealthy clients in France evade taxes, as Switzerland's largest bank struggles to turn the page on legal entanglements stemming from its core wealth-management business.

title: West Virginia Teachers Walk Out for Second Day
summary: Unions want to ensure lawmakers don't reintroduce legislation to create charter schools. West Virginia teachers walked out for a second day Wednesday, closing schools across the state over concerns Republican lawmakers could revive legislation to create the state's first charter schools.

title: Nonprofits Grow Uneasy With Philanthropy Tainted by Opioid Proceeds
summary: Columbia University reviews its philanthropic relationship with Purdue Pharma's Sackler family. Two prominent institutions, the New York Academy of Sciences and Columbia University, are joining the list of universities, museums and nonprofits currently reviewing their philanthropic relationships with members of the Sackler family, owners of pain-pill maker Purdue Pharma LP.

title: Huawei's Surveillance Business Hits Snag in Philippines
summary: Lawmakers balk at funding 'Safe City' project for Manila that they fear could enable Chinese spying. U.S. pressure on Huawei Technologies Co. is echoing in the Philippines, where lawmakers are pushing back against a $400 million video surveillance project that would use gear supplied by the Chinese company.

title: Wearing Your Coat Like a Cape: The Ultimate Female Power Move?
summary: From Melania Trump to Meghan Markle, the confounding practice with 1950s glamour roots has taken hold in the photo-op era. FASHION EDITORS do it. Instagram influencers definitely do it. First lady Melania Trump has done it for countless photo ops; Kim Kardashian West has done it in Paris. Last spring, Meghan Markle notably did it on her way to a royal engagement in London. Occasionally, Jimmy Fallon does it, too, when shimmying on stage at "The Tonight Show."

title: Oil Companies in South Sudan Could Be Complicit in War Crimes, U.N. Says
summary: Report describes atrocities by government-controlled security forces, which are funded by oil proceeds. Oil companies operating in South Sudan could be complicit in war crimes, as oil proceeds are funding the government-controlled security forces in the country's brutal civil war, the United Nations said Wednesday.

title: Swiss Bank UBS Has a Bad Day in French Court
summary: A $5.1 billion penalty against UBS could damage the bank's balance sheet and puts its share buybacks at risk. Money laundering is big business, but fines for banks caught assisting it have been relatively small. Until now.

title: Will the Oscar Finally Go to These Hollywood Veterans?
summary: An Oscar win, or even a nomination, has long eluded some stars despite their critically acclaimed careers. It's not an official Oscar category or even a real thing, yet multiple nominees will be vying for an It's About Time award on Sunday.

title: South Africa Bails Out Scandal-Struck Power Company
summary: Failures at Eskom's aging power stations and technical problems at newer plants have led to debilitating blackouts. PRETORIA, South Africa-The South African government announced a $5 billion bailout of its troubled power utility Wednesday as part of a tough national budget less than three months ahead of elections.

title: The Community Obama Still Can't Organize
summary: America's 44th President faces a new challenge to his Chicago building plans.. More than three decades ago, a young Columbia University grad named Barack Obamastruggled mightily as a community organizer in Chicago. A federal judicial ruling this week suggests that even after serving two terms as President of the United States, Mr. Obama is still trying to figure out how to organize Chicago communities.

title: Wellness Getaways That Come With Tequila
summary: From Sedona to Yucátan, these no-judgment spa resorts offer top health-boosting treatments-plus utterly hedonistic indulgences. AIRLINES TREAT fliers to guided meditation videos, fine hotels employ shamans and India's time-honored ayurvedic therapies have become spa staples around the world. In short, wellness getaways are alive and well. Grueling, low-cal, high-cardio regimens still have plenty of overachieving fans, but resorts like the four here cater to another clientele. Their guests don't want Pilates classes or sunrise boot camps to pre-empt the indulgences that make vacations worth waiting for. Is there any reason to forgo fine tequila or a slab of cake for the sake of a more virtuous triangle pose? Of course not.

title: India Finds Limited Options as Modi Crafts Response to Kashmir Attack
summary: Shifting state of global geopolitics and the winter weather offer prime minister fewer options than after past attacks. summary: Drugstore chain and insurer says weak guidance is due to fewer price increases on brand-name drugs. CVS Health has a drug-pricing problem: Manufacturers aren't raising their prices quickly enough.

summary: Long-tenured executives worry their skills may not translate, but firms increasingly are open to hiring outside leaders. Executives often find it hard to jump ship after helping to steer the same workplace for years.

summary: The last surviving prosecutor of the Nuremberg Trials is the subject of a new documentary.

summary: Insurance policies go back to the ancient Babylonians and were crucial in the early development of capitalism.

As the skies get more crowded, the Federal Aviation Administration is making changes to air-traffic control in hopes of avoiding the kind of widespread delays that travelers experienced routinely 20 years ago.

title: U.S. Soccer President's American Ambition
summary: One year in, Carlos Cordeiro addresses youth soccer's malaise, a possible national training center and why the U.S. shouldn't rest on its women's team laurels. The president of U.S. Soccer acknowledges the federation doesn't actually know how many young soccer players it has playing under its umbrella. He does know that participation isn't growing.

title: PetSmart vs. Petco: A Dogfight That Neither One Is Winning
summary: After private-equity takeovers, one firm bet big on internet sales and the other is trying to get people back into stores. Private-equity firms bought America's two biggest pet-store owners within months of each other. One spent billions to boost its online business by acquiring the top internet pet retailer. The other focused on getting people back in stores.

title: Tesla Replaces Top Lawyer After Two Months in Latest Major Departure
summary: Veteran trial lawyer Dane Butswinkas returns to a law firm, while company insider Jonathan Chang takes his place. Tesla Inc. is losing its general counsel after just two months on the job, replacing the veteran trial lawyer with a longtime insider who helped the electric-car company navigate some of its biggest legal issues.

title: Former Chinese Military Chief Gets Life in Prison for Corruption
summary: Fang Fenghui among highest-ranking generals snared by Xi's sweeping campaign to cleanse graft from army. BEIJING-A Chinese military court sentenced a former top commander to life in prison for corruption, in a case state media has portrayed as a sign of President Xi Jinping's commitment to stamp out graft in the armed forces.

summary: Mondelez shares are expensive given the near-term risks to global growth. Why pay up for a company with no real revenue growth, especially when the company does a lot of its business in the riskiest markets?

summary: Manitoba Harvest Hemp Foods, which supplies snacks, protein blends and oil, was sold to Canada's Tilray. Market participants are growing confident that the European Central Bank will soon try to boost the eurozone's ailing economy by rebooting its program of ultracheap long-term loans to the banking system.

title: Green New Deal Won't Enjoy a Free Lunch at the Fed
summary: Fed can't make a Green New Deal cheaper without compromising its control of interest rates and thus inflation. When advocates of a Green New Deal are asked how the U.S. can afford its lavish promises of 100% renewable energy, millions of high-paid jobs and Medicare for all, they have a ready reply.

title: Amazon's Ad Business May Be Growing Faster Than Thought
summary: Research firm eMarketer revises its estimates upward, again. Amazon.com Inc.'s ad business is again outstripping earlier projections.

title: Walmart's Multibillion-Dollar U.K. Merger Faces Big Hurdle
summary: U.K. regulators say a deal between Walmart's Asda and local grocer Sainsbury could push up prices. British regulators said they were leaning toward blocking a proposed merger between Walmart Inc.'s British grocery unit and rival J Sainsbury PLC, threatening to scuttle one of the retail giant's biggest overseas overhauls.

title: Fed Minutes May Yield Clues to How Long Rate Pause Will Last
summary: Central bank officials are also discussing how and when to end runoff of $4 trillion asset portfolio. The Federal Reserve releases the minutes of its Jan. 29-30 meeting on Wednesday at 2 p.m. EST, providing more detail about officials' discussions before they formally signaled a halt to interest rate rises.

title: Venezuela Opposition's Citgo Takeover Disappoints U.S.
summary: Opposition leader Juan Guaidó's board appointments fell short of what U.S. officials wanted, people familiar with the matter say. U.S. efforts to transfer control of Citgo Petroleum Corp. to Venezuela's opposition leaders have hit a snag, potentially undermining Washington's appetite to protect the Houston-based company from creditors, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Alibaba and the Wasteful Investment Bank Deal
summary: The decision to build a stake in CICC is new evidence of a misguided investment strategy. Imagine Amazon gate-crashing a party between Facebook and Goldman Sachs . The equivalent has just happened in China, with Alibaba raising its stake in investment bank CICC to nearly 5%.

title: Asia's Most Radical Left-Wing Economic Program Faces a Harsh Reality
summary: Steep increases in Korea's minimum wage are weighing on employment and threatening the domestic economy. South Korea is often vaunted as one of capitalism's biggest success stories. These days, it's home to the one of the world's boldest left-wing economic programs.

title: Stock Investors Look Past Gloomy Trade Data
summary: Japan endured a sharper-than-expected drop in exports last month. Japan endured a sharper-than-expected drop in exports last month, the latest indication that global growth is decelerating. Stock investors seem unflustered.

title: Indonesia's Indosat Exploring Sale of Telecom Towers
summary: The deal could be valued at more than $1 billion. Indonesia's third-largest mobile operator is looking to sell some of its telecommunications towers in a deal that could be valued at more than $1 billion, people with knowledge of the process said.

title: Corporate Controllers Step Into the Spotlight as CFO Role Evolves
summary: Controllers are increasingly tasked with managing financial talent and deploying new technology, such as robotics and artificial intelligence, as finance chiefs delegate more. The role of the corporate controller, often the finance chief's second-in-command, is expanding as CFOs delegate more of their traditional finance leadership work-a stressful evolution for some finance veterans who are stretching beyond their historic focus on process and efficiency.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: White House Picks Jeffrey Rosen for Deputy Attorney General
summary: Seasoned bureaucrat would succeed Rod Rosenstein in running day-to-day operations at department hit by political storms. WASHINGTON-The White House on Tuesday selected Jeffrey Rosen, the No. 2 official at the Transportation Department, to be deputy attorney general, putting a seasoned bureaucrat in charge of the day-to-day operations of a Justice Department battered by political storms and suffering strained morale.

title: Trump Eases Off Hard Deadline for China Tariffs
summary: The March 1 deadline to complete talks with Beijing is 'not a magical date,' U.S. president says. WASHINGTON-President Trump gave his firmest indication yet that the U.S. may not increase tariffs on Chinese goods on March 1, as scheduled, despite statements by his top trade official that the U.S. should stick to a firm deadline.

title: Queens Politicians Feel the Heat Over Doomed Amazon Deal
summary: 'At some point you have to let the political chips fall where they may,' says New York City Councilman Jimmy Van Bramer. Two Queens politicians who were fierce critics of the deal to build a new Amazon.com Inc. campus in their districts have faced blowback from residents and business owners since the company ditched the plan.

title: Flynn Pushed Saudi Nuclear-Plant Plan Despite Warnings
summary: Mike Flynn and others within the White House ignored repeated legal and ethical warnings, according to House report. WASHINGTON-Former national security adviser Mike Flynn and others within the White House ignored repeated legal and ethical warnings as they pushed early in President Trump's tenure a plan to build dozens of nuclear-power reactors in Saudi Arabia, according to a report by a House panel released on Tuesday.

title: Pentagon Cloud-Computing Contract Sought by Amazon Faces New Hurdle
summary: A federal judge delayed a lawsuit at the Pentagon's request to allow it more time to investigate a possible conflict involving an Amazon executive. WASHINGTON-A federal judge delayed a lawsuit over a massive Pentagon cloud-computing contract Amazon.com Inc. was favored to win so the government could investigate what it said was "new information" on possible conflicts of interest in the procurement process.

title: Federal Government to Cancel Funds for California High-Speed Rail
summary: Trump administration halts $928 million in aid; Gov. Newsom calls move 'retribution' over wall suit. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration said Tuesday it would cancel almost $1 billion in funding for the California high-speed rail network, casting doubt on whether the state will be able to complete even the first phase of the troubled project.

title: FDA Warns on Services Offering Injections of Young Blood Plasma
summary: Unapproved services for Alzheimer's, Parkinson's and other diseases have been reported. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has warned older Americans away from services in several states that offer to inject them with younger people's blood plasma as a treatment for dementia, Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease and other debilitating maladies.

title: Chicago Police, Prosecutors Interview Brothers in Jussie Smollett Case
summary: Police dismiss earlier tip that they had been seen in elevator with Smollett. Chicago police and prosecutors on Tuesday interviewed the two brothers who purchased the rope used in the alleged racist and antigay attack reported by "Empire" actor Jussie Smollett last month, authorities said.
